title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SALT LAKE CITY — On a night defined by grit and a grinding Western Conference battle, one man refused to let his team’s season end. In a defensive war where points were a precious commodity, Hakeem Olajuwon authored a masterpiece, carrying the Houston Rockets to a heart-stopping 75-72 victory over the Utah Jazz with a playoff performance for the ages.

The final score, a relic from a bygone era of basketball, belies the singular brilliance on display. While the Utah Jazz fought valiantly, with Karl Malone battling for 23 points and 15 rebounds, they had no answer for the force of nature wearing Rockets red. Olajuwon was simply transcendent, pouring in a game-high 37 points and dominating the glass with 14 rebounds. In a game where no other player cracked 20 points, "The Dream" was the entire offensive system, a beacon of consistency in a sea of missed shots.

The Jazz, led by Malone’s physicality and John Stockton’s 13 points and 9 assists, threw everything they had at the Rockets’ center, but to no avail. Clyde Drexler’s supporting role of 12 points and 7 rebounds was crucial, but this was Olajuwon’s stage. Every clutch basket, every key defensive stop, emanated from him.

In the end, with the game hanging in the balance, it was Olajuwon’s will that proved the difference. His monumental 37-point effort, in such a low-scoring affair, stands as one of the most dominant and essential carry-jobs in playoff history, a testament to a legend who simply would not be denied.
